content:
We'd like to announce that we have just released the new 1.4.0 version of the FHIR .NET API. This is mostly a bugfix release and we focused on slice validation. You can read the full releases notes here.

Of course, you can find the binary distribution on NuGet and the sources for the master branches on GitHub.

I downloaded the source code, but there appears to be a lot missing (e.g. no Hl7.Fhir.ElementModel and Hl7.Fhir.Serialization projects). The solution file is in the root folder, rather than the src folder, and contains references to projects in the common folder that aren't there. Am I missing some instructions as to how to retrieve all these things?

@Peter Jordan We recently split of some logic common to STU3 & R4. You also need this:
https://github.com/FirelyTeam/fhir-net-common
The common repo is a submodule of the main fhir .net api repo

We use submodules now in our source code. Common is such a submodule. So when you want to clone our source code, you should also update the submodule common. Some Git clients do that automatically, but some don't.

When you are using the Git CLI use can do the following:

  git clone --recurse-submodules https://github.com/FirelyTeam/fhir-net-api.git .

Then everything is cloned correctly.

I will update this information on our Wiki page. Thanks for noticing it.

All good now. I did fall into one trap (i.e. did something daft) which was to use the Dev version of Common with the release version of Main! This caused errors as a more recent version of system.net.http is now used in Dev.

Indeed, Checking out both repositories separately can cause errors. With submodules there will be a "pointer" in the main repo to the commit in the submodule, so the main repo does know how to checkout the submodule.

Git submodules are fairly new. Tooling support still needs to mature a bit. Submodules simplify (no pun intended) the management of our FHIR API repos for STU3 & R4 on Git, but they also introduce some new (tooling) challenges. After consultation with e.g. Microsoft, we decided that the technology was sufficiently stable to adopt. I expect tooling to follow suite.
While it depends on the tool of course, from my experience the tooling is there - now is the user education part
Submodules got repaired some years ago to make sense and the tooling in the last 1-2 years is there. People just don't know much about them yet
Indeed, we do need to get some more experience with submodules.
